item.title: NEEDS WORK Why is Everyone Anxious These Days
item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm
item.content:encoded:
It's generally not a good idea to draw broad conclusions about what things are like "these days". For one thing, most of us weren't around for most of the past. Sure, we might have some idea of what life was like in the 1800s, but even historians don't know everything. And amateurs like me certainly don't. Even today, we don't know exactly how prevalent anxiety is. Amongst other reasons, people often live with it silently, each imagining "I'm the only one". So comparing the prevalence of anxiety today to how it was in the past is foolish, and guaranteed to be wrong. Nevertheless, I'm going to do it. Inner critic: Me doing something foolish? How very surprising...

AMDSOFM

Despite everything I just said about it being hard to compare the situation today to the past, it seems intuitive and incontestable that there's a lot more anxiety around than there used to be. Not only do stats show [insert stat] But it just seems believable given everything we know about modern society. I try to avoid amateur sociology, but it doesn't seem hard to guess why.

A World Made for Anxiety

If you were designing a society with the aim of creating the most anxious population possible, what would you do? (It's probably best not to wonder WHY you would do anything as unpleasant as this. Let's just imagine there's some excellent reason.) Here's what I'd do. First, I'd instil anxiety early. The best way to do this would be to set up some sort of system which every child must pass through. This system would judge them in increasingly stressful situations for as long as I could persuade people it was necessary. Ideally, this judgement would involve setting all children against one another and branding them with permanent records of their successes (and failures!) in this competition. I'd be sure to remind all children as often as possible that everything they do matters forever and will have long-lasting and unpredictable consequences. This would prevent them from every truly being able to relax, as they'd feel constantly watched, judged and evaluated. I'd also tell them that perfect standards exist. Believing that perfection is attainable is a great way to get someone to continually beat themselves up. After children have passed through that system, I would create another system, mostly made up of busywork which is disconnected from any personal meaning. Of course, it wouldn't be possible to make ALL jobs meaningless. Some jobs obviously matter at a very direct and human level - they save lives, feed people, build homes. If, by accident, we allow jobs with direct personal meaning to exist, we should ensure that they're as stifled as possible with paperwork and measurement. Just as measurement kills all joy in childhood, it can kill all freedom in adulthood. The media is another important component in an anxious society. Advertising must be prominent and inescapable, and it must always push the idea that your life lacks worth. For extra points, provide a false solution to any problems we may have: so we're fooled by advertising into buying products that they pretend will make us feel better, but actually do nothing of the sort. Then we spend the money we don't have on products we don't need to fill the anxious hole created by everything else in society. Social media is also useful as it provides an endless series of possibilities for comparison. For all the good social media can do, most people will censor most of what they post, so scrolling through your friend's feeds jsut shows image after image of perfection and happiness, which you can compare to your own life and feel terrible about. Politics should be remote, uncaring and inhumane. Ideally the very worst, most selfish people in society would rise to the top and ruthlessly resist any suggestion that a fairer world is possible. In fact, believing in a fairer world ought to be met with mockery - if we can teach people that believing in fairness is itself a flaw, then the anxious world becomes ever more self-sustaining. Local community should be spread out. The unintended consequence of giving everyone better transport is that they'll no longer live close to their family or friends, so everyone becomes lonelier.

There's No Evil Mastermind

None of this is perpetrated by some villain. Nobody is sitting around designing these situations. It's just systems. Human-created self-perpetuating systems. Unfortunately, the combination of all the systems we live with in the modern world tends to be crushing. But that's a good thing. It might seem easier if it was like in stories, and there was some mustachio'd villain twirling and cackling as they design these oppressive systems.* But humans created these systems, and humans can change them. Not as individuals. Most of these things are too huge for any one person. But we can do something. We can take off our masks on social media. We can vote for less shitty politicians (this one is hard, given recent political events). We can stop buying awful media, or responding to negative advertising. And so on... By each playing a little part, maybe we can make the world a little less anxious for us all. * obviously some villains do really exist, and some people do take joy in the oppression of others. These people are dicks, and we should do something about it when and if we can. But they're not what I'm talking about today.

Before I’d write pages of the arguments that the inner voice would give me eg “I am worthy to make art” …. No you’re not who do you think you are” and other highly original stuff. But this time I have used your idea and I use a dark bold pen to write affirmations on how brilliant I am J and use a wispy light pen to argue AND within a couple of times the blurts have stopped or I sense the inner hurt child and can answer that and pow I’m healed … well not totally but you get the idea J

item.title: Death & Health Anxiety
item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm
item.content:encoded:
blog series 1) acceptance of death 2) health anxiety - refers back to the acceptance of death as a necessary step
Ah, health anxiety. I've been around that loop SO often. For a long time I felt that it was too hard for me to write about (I didn't write about it specifically in the book, and I'm yet to blog about it) because it was too close to the bone even though I've been through so much work on understanding and unpicking my anxiety.
I guess my belief is that the same techniques can work with health anxiety as worked for everything else, and I think that's right.
These days I tend to have a several-pronged approach when I get convinced I've potentially got cancer/some weird rare disease/the usual things. These thoughts may or may not be useful for you, I have no idea, but they seem to work for me at reducing the anxiety.
First I work on accepting that I do have whatever it is. (This is, I think, a fairly advanced move that is only possible because I've spent so long grappling with existential issues like death, so I suspect that this would be a counter-productive step for most people... BUT once you've done a lot of existential work it really provides a helpful strength for health anxiety). I literally just think "okay, so I've got x and I'm going to die now. I guess I've had 30 or so good years, more than most." Super weirdly this helps - I think my brain is much more comfortable with a certain horror than an uncertain horror.
Then I'm free to apply a bit of rationality to it. I can look at the actual probability that I have whatever it is (which is usually close to 0%!). Then I remind myself I live in a country with excellent free medical care and allow gratitude for not being American to reduce the feeling further.
Lastly, I decide whether or not to see a doctor about it. Often the answer is no, and a couple of days later I've forgotten all about it. Sometimes the answer is yes and I then get lost in something else - everytime the thought comes back I think "I'm seeing the doctor on Thursday / in a week / in ten months" and let that be the final word on it. If I then think "what if it gets worse" I lean into it like I did with the death thing - "yes, it WILL get worse" and paradoxically focusing on that makes me feel weirdly certain that it won't. And then I think "even if it does get worse, I'll go for emergency care. Nothing else to do."
Again, the focus is just on whatever I can do, which is basically very little: go to a doctor, or not. Everything else I drop.
I'm not perfect at this, obviously, but these days health anxiety tends to knock me out for hours at a time, and not weeks/months so I must be doing something right. I have no idea how much of that is translatable into your life, but thought I'd share in case any of it is, as I know how utterly horrible and crippling and all-consuming health anxiety is.

item.title: Alone
item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm
item.content:encoded: I've been travelling for the last three weeks, and as a result have spent a fair bit of time alone. (About half the time I've been away I've been with old friends or new people so please don't worry about me - this post is not a whinge about being lonely!) This isn't unusual. I often spend time alone at home. But there's a special kind of solitude that you get when you're halfway around the world and also alone. Solitude is one of those issues which has recurred for me throughout my life. While I've always been happy with my own company, it's taken many years to become truly comfortable with it, even to enjoy it. Some difficult things have happened during these weeks - both at home and over here - and it would have been easy to fall into old anxious traps. But I didn't

item.title: ** NEXT ** EXTRAPOLATION -
item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm
item.content:encoded:
don't extrapolate from your current position.
things go up/down, up/down. you may be on a downward trajectory right now, but what's the overall picture?
lots of graphs, including a wiggly one that trends up. show how you can wrongly extrapolate to the bottom.
gently allow yourself to occasionally fail, but look at the bigger picture
and if you're genuinely on a downward trend - you might be - then what can you do to slow it? change direction? it's always possible to do SOMETHING, even if it's only thinking hopeful thoughts.
Always look at reality where possible

item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm

you are, really.
"He made me angry"
He didn't. He did something. You became angry.
(Okay, many times it's totally valid to be angry, I'm not questioning the emotion itself, just the process that leads to it. We have more control than we realise, and that's awesome. Means we can take a little more ownership of anger/frustration/sadness/fear, and let go of it when it doesn't matter.
I mean, does it REALLY matter when this happens? Sometimes not.

item.title: Why Do We Suffer Alone
item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm
item.content:encoded:
It seems common then, that we often choose to suffer alone rather than bother other people with our struggles. It makes me wonder, is the problem that society as a whole sucks? Is society as a whole untrustworthy? Or maybe the problem has something to do with our close friend group? Or is it something more personal and internal that's just holding us back, that we feel the need to shoulder our burdens on our own? Wild self-sufficiency is both comfortable and uncomfortable. Comfortable in that it suffices our need to be independent, strong, dependable. And uncomfortable in that some burdens really are too much to carry alone. But regardless, we usually assume that the pain of struggling in silence is less than what we would face if we tried to share with a friend and were simply misunderstood or brushed off - or worse, rejected. Or maybe we just don't want to put anyone else what we're going through...
I have many thoughts on why we choose to suffer in silence rather than share (in fact, you've given me an idea for another post!). But I think you hit the nail on the head when you talk about fear of rejection. I don't think society sucks... in fact, my experience of talking publicly about mental health is that it usually leads to a huge outpouring of support and people saying "me too". That's why I think it's so important to do so.
I think we're naturally social animals, and most animals fear being singled out. The weakest animal in the pack often doesn't survive in nature... and we have millions of years of evolution giving us instincts to survive. But anxiety isn't like a broken leg in the jungle, it's something we COULD share, but we fear being a burden, we fear being rejected, we fear isolation.
For me, although there are so many more reasons we suffer in silence that is the main one.

item.title: Why Not To Be Ashamed of Anxiety
item.dc:creator: enhughesiasm
item.content:encoded:
I want to revisit the idea of why we are reluctant to talk about anxiety, or admit to being anxious. We've seen that bottling it all up is a bad idea, and that being open is helpful for ourselves and for anyone else in the same boat. So why do we do this?

#1 "Something Wrong With Me"

I think a common a reason for keeping our anxiety a secret is that we - consciously or subconsciously - think it reflects badly on us, somehow. I certainly felt that if I was open about my anxiety that others would judge me. As with so many causes of anxiety, this concept gets tangled up with several others all at once:

Viewing Anxiety as a Personal Failing

Anxiety isn't some personal failing. It might be rooted in something medical, or it might be rooted in our own thinking patterns and habits. Or a bit of both. But either way it doesn't reflect badly on us. You wouldn't blame yourself for a physical injury (well, assuming you didn't get injured testing a home-made rocket powered sled down a busy highway while strapped to a tiger). It's the same with a mental situation like anxiety.

Believing we must be perfect

This is often tied to the
